title-group.article-title: Aging-Like Skin Changes Induced by Ultraviolet Irradiation in an Animal Model of Metabolic Syndrome

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Gerontological Nursing/Wound Care Management, Division of Health Science and Nursing, The University of Tokyo Graduate School of Medicine, Tokyo, Japan
2Department of Advanced Skin Care (Miss-Paris), Graduate School of Medicine, The University of Tokyo. Tokyo, Japan
3Department of Pathology, Toranomon Hospital, Tokyo, Japan
4Research Institute of Pharmaceutical Science, Musashino University, Tokyo, Japan

author-notes.corresp: Hiromi Sanada, RN, PhD, WOCN, Department of Gerontological Nursing/Wound Care Management, Division of Health Science and Nursing, The University of Tokyo Graduate School of Medicine, 7-3-1 Hongo, Bunkyo-ku, Tokyo 113-0033, Japan E-mail: hsanada-tky@umin.ac.jp

abstract.p: Both physiological skin aging and pathologic photo-aging caused by ultraviolet (UV) irradiation are mediated by latent inflammation and oxidative stress. Although numerous animal skin-aging models have used UV irradiation, most require massive doses or long-term irradiation. To establish a more refined skin-aging model, we focused on an animal model of metabolic syndrome (MS) because MS involves damage to various organs via oxidative stress or inflammation, similar to the changes associated with aging. We hypothesized that MS skin might exhibit more aging-like changes after milder, shorter-term UV irradiation than would normal animal skin under similar conditions, thus providing a useful model for skin aging. The authors therefore examined the skin from Tsumura Suzuki obese diabetic (TSOD) mice (MS model) and control Tsumura Suzuki non-obese (TSNO) mice before and after UV irradiation. Skin from TSOD mice had a thinner epidermis and dermis, a thicker fatty layer, reduced density and convolution of the fragmented collagen fibers, and upregulated expression of tumor necrosis factor (TNF)-α, a dual marker for inflammation and aging, compared to the skin from TSNO mice. UV irradiation affected TSOD skin more severely than TSNO skin, resulting in various changes resembling those in aged human skin, including damage to the dermis and subcutaneous fatty tissue, infiltration of inflammatory cells, and further upregulation of TNF-α expression. These results suggest that UV-irradiated TSOD mice may provide a new model of skin aging and imply that skin from humans with MS is more susceptible to UV- or aging-related damage than normal human skin.

body.p: Aging is generally considered to comprise two separate processes: physiological aging and pathologic aging (Goto, 2008). The latter of these is induced by external factors or diseases. In the case of skin aging, photo-aging induced by ultraviolet (UV) irradiation is an important example of a pathologic aging process (Craven et al., 1997). However, recent studies have revealed that physiological skin aging and photo-aging share common mediators, such as oxidative stress (Callaghan & Wilhelm, 2008). Physiological aging and photo-aging are indistinguishable in clinical observations of aged skin. UV irradiation has therefore recently come to be regarded as an established methodology for researching skin aging in vivo (Seo et al., 2009).

Various animal models have been used to investigate skin aging (Table 1 ). Genetic animal aging models include Klotho mice (Kuro-o et al., 1997) and SAM mice (Takeda et al., 1994). These animal models of progeria exhibit age-related changes in multiple organs and are often used for research into osteoporosis and atherosclerosis (Manya, Akasaka-Manya, & Endo, 2010). However, they may not be appropriate for skin-aging research because the skin-specific aging process may be influenced by the surrounding, aging organs. These mice are also susceptible to external stress and have a high rate of early death. Skin-specific aging changes can be observed in UV-irradiated hairless model mice (Haratake et al., 1997; Inomata et al., 2003; Kim, Sumiyoshi, Sakanaka, & Kimura, 2009; Kobayashi, 2006; Oberyszyn, Tober, Ross, & Robertson, 1998; Paz, Ferrari, Weill, Leoni, & Maglio, 2008; Yasuoka et al., 2005). However, massive doses and long durations (1 day–10 weeks) of UV irradiation are generally required in these studies, making such experiments time-consuming and difficult. A refined skin-aging model responsive to milder, shorter-term UV irradiation is therefore required.

caption.p: Advantages and Disadvantages of the Current and Previous Mouse Skin-Aging Models

tr.td:
Genetic animal models
Klotho (Kuro-o et al., 1997)
SAM (Takeda et al., 1994)

list-item.p: Appropriate for research into general aging
Used for research into osteoporosis, atherosclerosis, etc
Susceptible to environmental changes, with high mortality
Inappropriate for skin-aging research because skin changes may be influenced by aging of other organs
Appropriate for observing and studying skin-specific aging process
High UV dose required (540 J/m2 to 5 kJ/m2).
Long duration of irradiation required (24 hr–10 weeks)

tr.td: (Haratake et al., 1997; Inomata et al., 2003; Kim et al., 2009; Kobayashi, 2006; Oberyszyn et al., 1998; Paz et al., 2008; Yasuoka et al., 2005)

list-item.p: Appropriate for observing and studying skin-specific aging process
Effect of MS on aging can be investigated

fn.p: Note. MS = metabolic syndrome; UV = ultraviolet.

body.p:
In the present study, we focused on an animal model of metabolic syndrome (MS) for potential use in skin-aging research. MS is characterized by hypertension, insulin resistance and hyperlipidemia during middle age and later life. It is one of the mechanisms of pathologic aging and a predisposing factor for damage to various organs, including in the cardiovascular, cerebrovascular, and renal systems. These MS target organs are in a latent inflammatory state, and the condition is known to be mainly mediated by oxidative stress (Nagase et al., 2006; Goto, 2008), both of which are similar to that which occurs in the aging process. Few MS studies have explored the relationship between MS and skin disorders. However, some recent studies strongly suggest that there is mechanical vulnerability of the skin in MS patients (Smalls, Randall Wickett, & Visscher, 2006) and obese animals (Enser & Avery, 1984; Ezure & Amano, 2010). For example, Nagase and colleagues (2009) reported that pressure ulcers of the deep-tissue injury type, where initial damage of the muscle or adipose tissue near the bone is followed by immediate deterioration toward the superficial skin, occurred in middle-aged obese humans with suspected MS. Other reports have indicated an association between MS and psoriasis, a chronic inflammatory skin disease (Cohen et al., 2008). Based on these observations, we formulated two hypotheses:
Hypothesis 1: The skin in MS will exhibit latent inflammatory changes, suggesting that it is a target organ of MS;
Hypothesis 2: UV irradiation will evoke more drastic, aging-like changes in MS skin than in normal skin.
The purpose of this study was to test these hypotheses using the MS animal model and to establish a refined, novel model of skin aging based on milder, shorter-term UV irradiation than that required in previous models. We assessed aging-like changes by examining changes in gene expression and by immunohistochemical staining of tumor necrosis factor (TNF)-α, which is regarded as a dual marker for inflammation and aging (Paolisso et al., 1998; Paz et al., 2008). Novel clinical insights based on the results of this study may be relevant to early nursing interventions for MS or age-related skin vulnerability, bearing in mind the aging population of MS patients.

sec.title: Animals
sec.p: We obtained male Tsumura Suzuki obese diabetes (TSOD) mice (Iizuka et al., 2005; Suzuki, 1998; Suzuki et al., 1999; Suzuki, Iizuka, Tabuchi, Yanagisawa, & Kimura, 2002; Suzuki & Nakajima, 2005; Suzuki & Tabuchi, 1999; Takahashi et al., 2006) and male Tsumura Suzuki non-obese (TSNO) mice from the Institute of Animal Reproduction (Ibaraki, Japan). TSOD mice provide an animal model of MS, with symptoms such as visceral fat accumulation, insulin resistance, glucose and lipid metabolism disorders, a lower metabolic rate, and hypertension. TSNO mice are derived from the same ancestors as TSOD mice but do not develop such symptoms (Iizuka et al., 2005; Suzuki, 1998; Suzuki et al., 1999, 2002; Suzuki & Nakajima, 2005; Suzuki & Tabuchi, 1999). We used 12-week-old TSOD and TSNO mice after 1 week of acclimation because 12 weeks is considered to be middle aged, which is when MS becomes problematic in humans. The animal care conditions included room temperature at 23 ± 1°C, humidity at 55 ± 5%, and lights-on at 8 a.m. and lights-off at 8 p.m. We allowed the animals free access to sterilized water and gave them ad libitum powder-feed MF (Oriental Yeast Co., Ltd., Chiba, Japan). We handled all animals in accordance with the guidelines of the National Research Council (1996). The experimental animal ethics committees of the University of Tokyo and Musashino University approved this study.

sec.title: UV Irradiation and Skin Harvesting
sec.p: We divided the mice into four groups: TSNO control group, TSNO-UV group, TSOD control group, and TSOD-UV group (n = 5 in each group). We shaved hair from the backs of all mice using a hair remover and exposed the naked skin in the TSNO-UV and TSOD-UV groups to UV irradiation (290–380 nm, maximum 312 nm) for 90 min using a UV lamp at a distance of 20 cm (Kyokko Denki, Tokyo, Japan), for a total dose of 20 J/m2. We sacrificed the animals 24 hr after UV irradiation, as described previously (Khaskhely et al., 2002; Paz et al., 2008). We obtained irradiated skin samples from the back to the depth of the cutaneous muscle.
We maintained mice in the TSNO and TSOD control groups for 24 hr without UV irradiation and then collected skin samples as described above.

sec.title: Histologic Examination
sec.p: We fixed a portion of the skin samples harvested with 4% paraformaldehyde, dehydrated them through a graded series of alcohols and xylene, and embedded them in paraffin. We cut tissue samples into 5-μm-thick sections, deparaffinized them three times with xylene and rehydrated them through graded alcohols. Finally, we stained the sections with hematoxylin and eosin (HE) and examined them under a light microscope.

sec.title: Reverse Transcription-Polymerase Chain Reaction (RT-PCR) Analysis of Tnfa Gene Expression
sec.p: We homogenized another portion of the skin samples with 1 mL of RNA solvent reagent (Omega-Bio-Tek, Inc, Norcross, GA), added chloroform (200 μL; Wako, Osaka, Japan) to the homogenized samples, and centrifuged them at 4500×g at 4°C for 30 min. We collected the supernatants and added the same volume of 70% ethanol to each sample. We purified total RNA from each sample using Nucleospin® RNAII (Macherey-Nagel, Düren, Germany) according to the manufacturer’s instructions and performed reverse transcription (RT) using MJ Mini™ (Bio-Rad, Hercules, CA) and a high-capacity cDNA reverse transcription kit (Applied Biosystems, Foster City, CA).

We amplified the Tnfa gene encoding the TNF-α protein and, as an internal control, the glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase gene (Gapdh) using AmpliTaq Gold PCR Master Mix (Applied Biosystems). The primer sequences (5′→3′) were as follows: mouse Tnfa forward ACTGGCAGAAGAGGCACTCC and reverse GGGTCTGGGCCATAGAACTG (PCR product: 200 bp); mouse Gapdh forward TGGTGAAGGTCGGTGTGAAC and reverse TGAATTTGCCGTGAGTGGAG (PCR product: 162 bp). We initiated PCR at 95°C for 10 min, followed by 40 cycles of 95°C for 15 sec, 60°C for 15 sec, and 72°C for 30 sec, with a final extension step at 72°C for 1 min. We separated the PCR products by 1.5% agarose gel electrophoresis and visualized them with Sybr Green nucleoic acid gel stain (Roche, Basel, Switzerland) and a UV transilluminator. We semiquantitatively calculated Tnfa gene expression levels using Image-J software and normalized it by Gapdh gene expression levels.

sec.title: Immunohistochemical Analysis of TNF-α
sec.p: We processed the 5-μm-thick skin sections from the four groups for TNF-α immunostaining. We inactivated endogenous peroxidase activity by incubating the sections in 0.3% hydrogen peroxide/methanol for 30 min. We performed antigen retrieval by autoclaving the slides in 10 mM citrate buffer (pH 6.0) for 15 min and cooling them for 60 min. We detected TNF-α expression by incubating the slides with anti-TNF-α primary antibody (LifeSpan BioSciences, Seattle, WA; diluted 1:100) at room temperature for 60 min. After washing them three times with phosphate-buffered saline for 5 min each, we subsequently incubated sections with biotin-conjugated anti-mouse IgG antibody (Vector Laboratories, Burlingame, CA; diluted 1:1000) for 30 min at room temperature. We detected immunoreaction using a VectaStain ABC Kit (Vector Laboratories) with 3,3′-diaminobenzidine tetrahydrochloride substrate (Nacalai Tesque, Kyoto, Japan). Finally, we performed counterstaining using Mayer’s hematoxylin and observed the specimens under light microscopy.

sec.title: Statistical Analysis
sec.p: We analyzed Tnfa gene expression levels using two-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) and the Bonferroni correction and considered values of p < .05 to be statistically significant. We used SAS, version 9.1 (SAS Institute Inc. Cary, NC), for all statistical analyses.

sec.title: Differences in Skin Histology Between TSNO and TSOD Mice Before UV Irradiation
sec.p: Histologic examination revealed that the subcutaneous adipose tissue layer was thicker and the epidermis and dermis were thinner in the TSOD control group, as compared with the TSNO control group (Figure 1xA-1 and B-1). Notably, the adipocytes in the skin of the TSOD control group appeared to infiltrate into the narrow dermal dimples (arrowheads in Figure 1B-1). We observed no infiltration of inflammatory cells in either of the control groups. Close observation revealed that the density and convolution of the collagen fibers in the dermis were reduced in the TSOD control group, as compared with the TSNO control group (Figure 1A-2 and B-2). We also noted considerable fragmentation of the collagen fibers in the TSOD control group. These findings suggest that the skin in TSOD mice is weaker and more susceptible to physical damage than that in TSNO mice.

caption.p: Hematoxylin and eosin (HE) staining of dorsal skin samples from Tsumura Suzuki non-obese (TSNO) and Tsumura Suzuki obese diabetic (TSOD) control groups, without ultraviolet (UV) irradiation. A. TSNO control, 12-week male; B. TSOD control, 12-week male. a: epidermis; b: dermis; c: subcutaneous fat; d: collagen fibers. The subcutaneous adipose tissue layer in the TSOD control group was thicker and the epidermis and dermis were thinner than those in the TSNO control group. The density and convolution of the collagen fibers in the dermis were reduced in the TSOD control group, compared with the TSNO control group. The findings in the dermis can be more clearly seen in the magnified images (A-2 and B-2). Note infiltration of the adipose tissue toward the dermal dimples (arrowheads in B-1). A-1 and B-1: Bar = 100 μm. A-2 and B-2: Bar = 50 μm.

sec.title: Differences in Skin Histology Between TSNO and TSOD Mice After 90 Min UV Irradiation
sec.p: UV irradiation resulted in more remarkable histologic changes in the skin of TSOD-UV mice than in TSNO-UV mice (Figure 2B-1 and B-2). The epidermis was thinner with a greater infiltration of inflammatory cells in the TSOD-UV group, as compared to the TSNO-UV group. Collagen fibers in the dermis were also damaged down to the subcutaneous fatty layer in the TSOD-UV mice. These findings suggest that photo-aging-like changes in the skin evoked by UV irradiation were more prominent in TSOD mice than in TSNO mice.

caption.p: Hematoxylin and eosin (HE) staining of dorsal skin samples from the Tsumura Suzuki non-obese (TSNO) and Tsumura Suzuki obese diabetic (TSOD) groups 24 hr after 20 J/m2 ultraviolet (UV) irradiation. A. TSNO-UV; B. TSOD-UV. a: epidermis; b: dermis. The epidermis was thinner with remarkable infiltration of inflammatory cells (c) in the TSOD-UV group, as compared to the TSNO-UV group. Collagen fibers in the dermis were damaged down to the subcutaneous fatty layer in the TSOD-UV group. The findings in the dermis can be more clearly seen in the magnified images (A-2 and B-2). A-1 and B-1: Bar = 100 μm. A-2 and B-2: Bar = 50 μm.

sec.title: Changes in Tnfa Gene Expression and TNF-α Immunostaining Patterns in the Skin of TSNO and TSOD Mice After 90 Min UV Irradiation
sec.p: Tnfa gene expression was upregulated in the skin of TSOD mice, as compared with TSNO mice. Semiquantitative analysis revealed that the Tnfa mRNA expression level was significantly higher in the TSOD control group than in the TSNO control group (Figure 3 ). Tnfa mRNA expression was also significantly higher in the TSOD-UV group than in the TSNO-UV group after 20 J/m2 UV irradiation (F = 60.25, p < .0001 for group and UV exposure interaction effect, Figure 3).

caption.p: Semiquantitative analysis of Tnfa mRNA expression in the skin of Tsumura Suzuki non-obese (TSNO) and Tsumura Suzuki obese diabetic (TSOD) mice in the control (C) and ultraviolet (UV) exposure groups by reverse-transcription polymerase chain reaction. Tnfa mRNA expression level was higher in the TSOD control group than in the TSNO control group and was much higher in the TSOD-UV group. TSNO-C: TSNO control group; TSOD-C: TSOD control group. *p < .05.

sec.p: We examined the localization of enhanced TNF-α protein expression within the tissue sections by immunostaining. TNF-α staining was negative in the epidermis in the TSNO control group (Figure 4A-1), while the epidermis in the TSOD control group stained positive for TNF-α (Figure 4B-1). After UV irradiation, the epidermis was TNF-α-positive in both the TSNO-UV and the TSOD-UV groups (Figure 4A-2 and B-2).

caption.p: Tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-α) immunostaining of dorsal skin samples from Tsumura Suzuki non-obese (TSNO) and Tsumura Suzuki obese diabetic (TSOD) mice in the control and ultraviolet (UV) exposure groups. A-1. TSNO-control; A-2.TSNO-UV; B-1. TSOD-control; B-2. TSOD-UV. a: epidermis; b: dermis. Arrowheads indicate the TNF-α positive areas stained in brown color. Bar = 50 μm. TNF-α was positive in the epidermis in the TSNO-UV, TSOD control, and TSOD-UV groups but negative in the TSNO control group. Although the sebaceous gland appears to stain positively, it also appears positive in the negative control sections, possibly due to the presence of endogenous peroxidase.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: In the present study, we examined the gene and protein expression of TNF-α, a marker for inflammation and aging (Paolisso et al., 1998; Paz et al., 2008), in the skin of TSOD and TSNO mice, as well as the histology of the skin, before and after UV irradiation. The TSOD group served as a model for MS. Before UV irradiation, the skin was thinner and Tnfa gene expression was higher in the TSOD than in TSNO control groups, and TNF-α was localized to the epidermis in the TSOD group. UV irradiation induced more severe inflammatory tissue damage and higher Tnfa expression in the TSOD-UV group than in the TSNO-UV group. These results suggest that the skin is a target organ in MS, with latent pathologic aging properties, and that UV irradiation accelerates aging-like changes in MS skin relative to normal skin.

This study provides the first histologic analysis of the skin in an MS animal model, demonstrating the presence of thin skin, damaged collagen fibers in the dermis, and a thick fatty layer, which may be responsible for its susceptibility to physical stimuli. Ezure and Amano (2010) previously reported similar thinning of the skin induced by a high-fat diet in obese mice. They offered two possible explanations for the skin-thinning mechanism: either physical expansion of the fatty tissue compressing the dermis or a negative effect on dermal fibroblast viability caused by paracrine factors such as TNF-α or interleukin-6 derived from the hypertrophic adipose tissue. Similar mechanisms could have occurred in our model; in particular, the infiltration of adipocytes into the dermis suggests expansion of the thick adipose tissue.

The present study also showed for the first time that UV irradiation induced more drastic aging-like skin changes in TSOD MS mice than in TSNO mice. The skin in TSOD-UV mice showed a thinner epidermis, infiltration of inflammatory cells into the damaged dermis, and remarkable upregulation of Tnfa gene expression (Paolisso et al., 1998; Paz et al., 2008). Kuro-o and colleagues (1997) reported that the skin of Klotho mice also showed thinning of the epidermis and dermis and a reduced number of hair follicles, resembling human senile skin atrophy. Inomata and colleagues (2003) and Kim and colleagues (2009) found that UV-irradiated hairless mouse skin showed aging-like changes such as hypertrophic epidermis, wrinkles, decreased elasticity, and shortening, fragmentation, and irregular alignment of dermal collagen fibers. Khaskhely and colleagues (2002) and Paz and colleagues (2008) also reported epidermal localization of TNF-α protein in UV-irradiated hairless mouse skin.

The changes that we detected in TSOD-UV mice in the current study and that other researchers have detected in previous models of skin aging resemble, at least in part, the morphologic skin changes seen in elderly humans, including thinning of the epidermis and dermis (El-Domyati et al., 2002; Lavker, 1979), wrinkles (Kim et al., 2009), pigmentation, and reduced density and bundles of collagen fibers (Baumann, 2007). We therefore believe that TSOD-UV mice can provide a useful and novel animal skin aging model.

The TSOD-UV model has three important advantages over previous skin aging models (Table 1). First, it is more skin-specific than the Klotho or SAM mice, in which the aging process in the whole body can interfere with the skin phenotype. The TSOD-UV model shows skin specificity similar to the previous hairless mouse models with UV. Second, the TSOD-UV model has an advantage over the hairless-UV models, in that only mild UV irradiation (20 J/m2) for 90 min is necessary to induce the changes. Previous models have required high-dose UV irradiation with 540 J/m2 to 5 kJ/m2 and up to 10 weeks’ duration (Haratake et al., 1997; Inomata et al., 2003; Yasuoka et al., 2005). Finally, the new model represents an important missing link between MS status and skin aging, which has not been previously considered but is of potentially great clinical significance.

The restricted localization of TNF-α in the epidermis in the UV-irradiated mice helps to shed light on the mechanisms responsible for the aging-like changes in TSOD-UV mice. Interestingly, we also noted faint epidermal localization of TNF-α in TSOD mice without UV irradiation. These findings suggest that, in addition to the subcutaneous fat discussed above, inflammation in the epidermis may play a pivotal role in MS-associated skin aging. Further studies are needed to address these issues.

The results of this study imply that the skin of human MS patients may show increased sensitivity to UV, resulting in earlier manifestations of age-related skin troubles, including skin tears, pressure ulcers, wrinkles, senile freckles, and malignant changes. Because the number of MS patients is increasing, clinical problems related to these skin problems will become increasingly prevalent, and early nursing interventions will be needed. The TSOD-UV skin-aging model used in this study provides a fundamental scientific basis for the development of novel nursing techniques and interventions, such as the use of new creams, ointments, or sprays with anti-inflammatory effects.

fn.p: The authors declared no potential conflicts of interests with respect to the authorship and/or publication of this article.

The authors disclosed receipt of the following financial support for the research and/or authorship of this article: This work was supported by a grant-in-aid for scientific research from MEXT (Ministry of Education Culture, Sports, Science and Technology; No. 21659494).
